content.description: Slick route with a cool wide crack crux. If you feel like fist jamming or hand stacking at the obvious crux, think again. Easier for those who are taller.
content.location: On the south side of the canyon under the old highway bridge. Easy to set up a top rope with pro.

content.description: Climb up into a slick, secure chimney. Crux is exiting the chimney with a bomber fist/hand jam. Search for the key foothold to make your exit easier. Then climb the easy #4 size crack to the top (OW technique optional).
content.protection: Favors #3 and #4 size pro. Other options possible
content.location: Ten feet left of the Coffin Crack in the fencepost area.

content.description: This is the best EZ warm up on the wall.
content.location: Route is in the gully between Twin Cracks' and the Layback's landings.  Belay off the high boulder.

content.description: Twin Cracks is a wonderful hand crack. The crux is in the middle of the climb, where the left crack gets a little wide. It's another classic climb in at Upper Sullies. I really like this climb, it was my first crack climb. And was the start of an addiction to crack climbing.
content.protection: cams .75-3 bring some small chalks for the right crack. Like all of the climbs at Upper Sullies there is no fixed anchor, but it's pretty straight forward to use trad gear to build an anchor.
content.location: Just to the right of S crack. It's pretty obvious. You can either rappel into the canyon or there is a walk down by the pipeline a little farther down canyon.

content.description: Getting off the deck is the hardest part. The crux is in the first four or five moves, or if you are super tall like me, it's the first move. It is a truly classic climb for the area.
content.protection: small. There isn't a fixed anchor at the top, but it's pretty easy to throw some pieces in to make it a top rope if you want.
content.location: Just to the left of Twin Cracks on the south wall between the old railroad bridge and the pipe line.

content.description: Face climb with a slick bottom moves into a steep, thin and reachy upper section. Start about ten feet right of the Twin Cracks and three feet right of the Annihilator.
content.protection: Small nuts & micro cams. Probably best to leave this one to the TR.

content.description: Excellent climbing up a continuous crack. Fists or stacks down low narrowing to hands. Like many climbs in this area, the crux is at the start.
content.protection: C4's from .75 to #3, plus one #4 for the lower section. Possible nut placements higher on the route. Several horizontals could take small gear. No fixed anchors, long slings or cordelette useful for building a gear anchor.
content.location: Left of the fencepost 100' west of the trestle. Rappel or walk around beyond the pipeline.

content.description: A low angled, well featured crack.
content.protection: Singles to #2 and/or set of nuts.
content.location: Between easy twin left and S crack.  Located in the left facing open book climbers left of a small tree.

content.description: A fun fingers and thin hands crack in a a slight dihedral.  Excellent crack for the beginning leader because protection opportunities are plentiful.  (Note that this climb is rated 5.5 in the Prescott Climbing Guide.  I used that rating to preserve the intent of whoever first climbed it.  However, i’d say it’s closer to 5.7)
content.protection: Single rack from 0.5 - #3 black diamond.  Doubles in the 0.5 - #1 if you really wanted to sew it up.
content.location: Located on top of a boulder pile two cracks to the left of S crack in the twin cracks area.

content.description: This crack is just left of Fence Post Direct.  Mostly finger sized, with some cool little pockets.  You can exit straight up, or you can make a move to the right at the upper horizontal crack, and finish in the right crack.  Both about the same difficulty.  Very fun!  Tricky to set up as a top rope.
content.location: Left of Fence Post Direct, and right of Coffin Crack.

content.description: Jam up slick start and climb into large coffin-sized pod. Then overcome the pod (crux) and climb the handcrack to the top. Like many routes here, there is occasionally water at the bottom of this route.
Technical and steep start with smoe good moves down low.  Moving up the hand jams get better up to a bomber fist jam to finish things off.
content.location: To the right of the 5.6 which is just right of the layback.  Look for a faint landing area just below a nice hand crack.  Unlisted in any guidebook, though I am sure we were not the first ascenders.  A descent line if you've ticked off everything else in Upper Sullivan.

content.description: Good hands and slick feet off the deck, a few slightly wider sections along the way, but pretty good jams or stemming all the way up.
content.protection: Small-Med. Trad anchor at the top (watch out for loose blocks)
content.location: Five (or so) feet right of Twin Cracks.

content.description: The south wall of Upper Sullies.
